narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned intermediate level of Italian
L3 Italian was mostly review of grammar and structure learned beforehand, but it had a greater emphasis on putting these things into practice in conversation.
Improved italian fluency and grammar
I learned the basics of Italian and become a conversational speaker in Italian.
I learned Italian. This class focused more on reviewing grammar rules but new words and various topics related to Italian culture were also covered.
I learned more about Italian life and culture because we read stories, watched movies, learned about ppl etc., I learned grammar and sentence structure, developed speaking skills
I became comfortable in speak Italian in discussion and reading texts.

In this course, I reinforced and sharpened my verbal Italian skills, both written and oral, while thoroughly reviewing grammar concepts from previous semesters. More specifically, we worked through the first 7 Lessons/Units of the Immagina textbook, which reviewed present tense, reflexive and reciprocal verbs, pronouns, adjectives, passato prossimo, imperfetto, passato remoto, trapassato, imperative, partitives, adverbs, conditional tense, ad subjunctive mood. While all these topics were covered in earlier levels, Immagina covered them slightly more in depth compared to the previous textbooks, with more advanced readings and videos included as well. Therefore, grammatically this course served as a good review and sharpening, rather than a source of many new topics/learnings. This course also furthered my language skills through some outside readings, namely an excerpt from Dantes Divina Commedia and two films: Songe Napule and Pane e Tulipani. Finally, by creating small recorded videos on my hobbies and a famous Italian artist and via in-class discussions, I increased my comfort with speaking clearly and professionally in Italian.
I learned SO much italian through this course! vocab, more precise grammar, and a lot of cultural background! Totally recommend! and ALL the professors are amazing!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: speak in Italian for the entire course so it helps you develop problem-solving skills when you don't know a word or conjugation; no weaknesses
Strengths-- relaxed, open class that was engaging to attend; Deborah is awesome, as well, as she is kind, funny, and insightful.  Weaknesses-- tough to be on Zoom for this course everyday.

Strengths- Deborah is great, and the movies were entertaining 
Weakness- the readings (letteratura) are BORING and generally hard to follow
It is an enjoyable class to attend everyday and the workload was manageable.

Strengths: the small size made it easier to talk in class and participate, we used breakout rooms which were great to practice with other students, we watched movies, read stories, great professor

Weakness: none, overall a well structured language course

The course was easy to be engaged with several breakout rooms and opportunities for discussion. The class was structured well and reviewed the majority of Italian needed to feel comfortable with the language.

The greatest strengths of the course were the outstanding instruction and class atmosphere, as well as the daily seminars themselves. This was my third semester with Deborah, and other students/professors are always impressed by how much weve learned from her. She is demanding while also being understanding and reasonable, and her classes are very engaging overall. As a result, the daily classes were fun rather than tedious, and we were able to have quite lively discussions (for a morning Zoom class at least :). The main weaknesses of the course were the somewhat repetitive nature compared to previous levels and the lack of unstructured time for discussion. Almost all the technical grammar from this semester we had already learned, yet we still spent the great majority of our time on it in terms of homework, exams, etc. Class was almost always more fun and worthwhile when we had more open-ended discussion, though it was sometimes quiet/awkward; however, I think wed get more comfortable with it if we practiced more. In fact, the other main strength of the class was the instruction from outside the book, whether it was the weekly essays, which were fun and greatly increased my writing skills, or the two films, which led to more lively discussions. Similarly, I think doing more outside readings, like the Divine Comedy this semester or The Decameron last semester (or even more films) would greatly increase learning and engagement. We were much more adept at the Italian language, so we could definitely treat the course in a bit more of an advanced way.

I love the teaching format. the exercises we do and stories we read are entertaining as well as help us learn. I also did like the exam format, especially with online classes. there were a lot of exams, but it made the course easier to manage.

Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was done very well, but I had trouble submitting tests and video presentations sometimes.
They did a good job, given the circumstances. I especially appreciated that the exams were not over zoom.
Breakout rooms were helpful.

success: use of breakout rooms, sharing screens, engaging exercises

improvement: can't really think of anything
The use of breakout rooms was very helpful and was a good amount in comparison with group discussion. Asynchronous movies was also a nice break in the class rhythm.

In terms of virtual learning, the best practice of this course was honestly running it as close to normal. We still had synchronous daily classes, which kept me very engaged in the course, and the structure of homeworks, exams, etc. were also similar to in-person semesters. I think the synchronous format of exams worked well, though there were often some technological struggles so giving a bit of extra time was always a good decision. There are no major sources of improvement, but it would have been nice to do presentations live in class or at least watch our VoiceThread presentations together. Those always felt a bit disconnected and lost in the ether. Similarly, I know we had some kind of live YUAG presentation planned, which would have been more engaging than just making a video independently on it.
having a small class like this was tough, but the teachers in this department are very good at engaging the students and getting us to interact (ex. in breakout rooms). love the course both ways!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I recommend taking Italian because the professors care about teaching you more than just the grammatical aspects of the language and help to immerse you in the culture, while being supportive when you make mistakes
Yes, I recommend the Italian sequence in general to students thinking about taking a new language-- the department is awesome, the history is cool, and it is a manageable course overall.
Absolutely. Deborah is an amazing professor, and this was honestly a really fun class (even doing it online).
Yes, but Deborah is tougher than other italian professors (at least in my experience), especially in grading.
I would recommend this class to any student that needs to fulfill their language requirement. The Italian department is both fair and understanding. The workload was very manageable.
Yes, if you want to learn Italian or if you need to fulfill your foreign language requirement
yes!
The Italian department is incredibly kind and the courses are always interesting. I would definitely recommend studying Italian at Yale.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student looking to further solidify their basic understanding of Italian in a fun and manageable class setting. It follows a very similar structure to previous levels of Italian, with daily classes and a focus on grammar. However, there is also a decent focus on Italian culture, with occasional outside readings and films as well. I would not necessarily recommend this course to someone with an advanced background looking for an early advanced class focused on literature, as we only read occasional short stories and stuck mostly to the book. Nevertheless, I think anyone would get something out of the intensive grammar review, regardless of Italian background. And for someone looking to shore up their technical knowledge before moving to advanced classes, it is perfect. Most of all, this class is just a fun way to satisfy the language requirement and learn more about an amazing language and culture!

Totally take this course! the professors are amazing, and are also so good at making this course lots of fun! the work is very manageable, and as long as you are engaged each class and are putting in effort when in class, there is no need to worry about your grade!
